For 25 years I had the privilege of working in this lovely old building, In fact, my office was the single balcony on the extreme left of the photograph. It is not just an historic building but a working courthouse. It was built in 1926 after an earthquake destroyed the predecessor courthouse. In fact, the sunken gardens around which the present courthouse is built is roughly the foot print of the one destroyed. When you go, sit in on a trial, and go to the mural room for a pictorial history of Santa Barbara on three walls. At the top of the wing on Santa Barbara Street is the old jail which was in use into the 1990s for holding prisoners for court appearances. The county law library on the second floor has some nice mural/maps. The tiles around the building are an eclectic collection. Take the docent tour, and if you are with a group, call ahead and see if you can get a detailed tour from a representative of the county architect's office. Finally, go to the top of the clock tower for a wonderful view of the city and its red tiled roofs.

The Santa Barbara County Courthouse may look like a castle in southern Spain, but it is really a working courthouse with six superior courts, a hall of records, and numerous offices. It is also according to one architect, the finest example of Spanish Colonial Revival Architecture in the United States. Built after the 1925 earthquake in Santa Barbara, it was finished in 1929 at a cost of 1,368,000. The William Mosher company headed the architectural design and was in charge of the project. To really enjoy this Santa Barbara gem, take advantage of the free tours given daily. !0:30 and 2:00 during the week and 2:00 on the weekend. You will be amazed. Take the elevator to the tower - from there you have the best view in Santa Barbara.

The Courthouse is, as the name says, the seat of law in Santa Barbara. So most tourists might say "that's boring, let's skip that". But the Santa Barbara Courthouse is much more than that. In many ways it is the heart of the city. During the Fiesta, and at other times of the year as well, the Sunken Garden (a large lawn on the inside of the "L" formed by the Court building) serves as an outdoor theater. This is where people sit while an elevated stage is erected next to the outside stairway. Various organizations hold award ceremonies and other such events here. The building is probably the best example of the Spanish Mission style that was invented in and for Santa Barbara and is not found anywhere else, since this style is a merging of several different architectural styles. The building is beautiful inside and out. Be sure to stop at the second floor mural courtroom that depicts the history of this area. It is usually open and sign near the elevator will indicate how to get there. This room also serves occasionally for evening concerts. Finally, be sure to take the elevator to the top floor and then take stairs one more floor up to the observation deck, the only such place in Santa Barbara. If you want to go inside the building, you will have to come during regular business hours. However, the building is also really beautiful at night, when it is lit up. But then you can just look, you cannot explore the inside or go to the observation deck. For couples looking for a place to get married, the Courthouse has I think 2 or 3 different options, and you could hardly find a prettier setting. Parking is free for the first 75 minutes across the street next to the Public Library, in a large parking complex (off Anacapa). There are other parking structures downtown as well, but this is the closest one.

This magnificent example of Spanish Colonial Revival style architecture sits on 5 acres of lawns and gardens. Completed in 1929, it was the site of the infamous Michael Jackson trial in 2005 and is the site of musical and cultural events, usually on Sundays, throughout the year. It is the featured site of three nights of Noches de Rondo (the premier musical and dancing events of the annual Santa Barbara Fiesta celebration held during the first week of May). Climb to the top of the tower for magnificent 360 degree views of the city, the mountains and the ocean. Tours are available Monday through Saturday. Call the visitor booth (805) 962-6464 for information.
